awd_abstract_narration:
This project creates an I-Corps Site at the Technology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization Institute (TEC) at Ohio State (OSU).

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

TEC at OSU has a track record in commercializing university technologies and training STEM and business students and is the primary market intelligence and business modeling entity, working with the Office of Research and the Technology Commercialization Office and partnering with more than a dozen colleges, department, research centers, and funded programs across campus. TEC has trained more than 500 graduate students and more than 40 research faculty using the Lean Startup curriculum, generating 27 new ventures that raised more than $40 million. TEC recently established a new initiative to support technology commercialization ? the Faculty Certification Program in Technology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization. This certification program uses an innovative pedagogy to train research faculty and their startup teams in the principles and techniques of commercialization via startup. 

The combined impact of the TEC Institute?s I-Corps@Ohio program and the new Faculty Certification Program is important for Central Ohio and across the state. The specific impact of the NSF I-Corps Sites funding is realized in:
1) An increase in the number of Ohio State teams that participate in the training program, 
2) A greater number of STEM graduate students that matriculate to entrepreneurial leads in technology startups, and 
3) More new technology startups that raise capital and launch in Ohio. 

Secondary outcomes that provide broad impacts are:
1) An increase in the number of inventions resulting from federally-funded research that are screened for commercial potential,
2) More new products and services providing innovative solutions to problems in healthcare, environmental sustainability, national security, food safety, etc., and 
3) Greater return on innovation investment for Ohio State. 

As successful ventures make their way to market, an additional outcome with big market impact is the number of research scientists that seek out training in advanced principles for commercialization because they recognize commercial markets on par with federal and state grants for career advancement and sustained funding for technology development.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Ohio State University's Center for Design and Manufacturing Excellence (CDME) was awarded with the opportunity to provide aid and support to the identified I-Corps team projects of: (1) Primal Points (Kent State), (2) Upcycled Postrock (University of Michigan), (3) SmartForm & BREATHE-Smart (OSU), and (4) Universal Gripper (OSU). Upon selection, CDME researchers reviewed the proposed tasks of each team to develop insights and address such areas of opportunity that would advocate for the advancement of the associated I-Corps team's technology readiness level (TRL) goals.

Primal Points

The Kent State University I-Corps project team identified a market opportunity to reverse engineer and manufacture modern metal broadheads. Through the course of the project, the team encountered several technical hurdles in advancing the concept to a manufacturable prototype; problems that CDME explored.

Through collaborative discussion with the Primal Points team and researchers at CDME, a short list of tasks was identified that would help the team advance their concept towards launch, consisting of 3D Model Preparation, Preparation of Wax Forms, and Digitization of Additional Designs.

CDME's efforts delivered the revised digital model, 3D printed wax forms, and molds to produce additional samples to the Primal Points team, advancing the state of Primal Points' product development and moving the needle towards product launch.

Upcycled Postrock

The University of Michigan's I-Corps team has been researching the upcycling potential of plastic waste from a local industry partner into architectural applications. CDME was tasked with analyzing the list of feedstocks from the industry partner then provide analysis and details of an approach to material selection.

Upon recognition of the material selection of Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET)9, Polypropylene (PP)9, High Density Polyethylene (HDPE)9, Low Density Polyethylene (LDPE)9, and Polystyrene (PS)9, a list of tasks was determined to Analyze the Highest Streams of Waste by Weight, Identify Desired Materials, and Define Material Characteristics.

CDME's assistance optimized the likelihood of success from utilizing an optimal blend of feedstock with a collection of properties that enhance the functionality of the product. Overall, the matching of materials to one another for property enhancement can be improved with the use of a multitude of compatibilizers or additives.

SmartForm & BREATHE-Smart

CDME and the project team's collaboration was directed towards the improvements of the BREATHE-Smart design regarding the polymer 3D-printed cases utilized for encasing the lateral flow immunoassay (LFIA) testing sensor, sensing for the detection of mold within the home. Additional efforts included acquirement of parts and the process of 3D-printing such encasing units for a low-cost self-built Lateral Flow Reagent Dispenser (LFRD) that will be necessary to manufacture the sensors.

CDME has achieved the partial assembly of the LFRD from the printed and procured parts. Areas of improvement have been identified in the BREATHE-Smart design that will be addressed prior to the final assembly and functionality and effectiveness assessment.

A novel chemical compound mixture has been developed in association to SmartForm that provides optimal color change when exposed to formaldehyde. Through this discovery the process of detecting mold can be directly associated to the color change from mold exposure. The next steps include licensing the technology to a local company that will create inexpensive home testing kits that will be integrated into their current product offering. 

Universal Gripper

The Ohio State University project team recently invented a variable stiffness compliant robotic gripper (VSCRG) that is flexible enough for adapting to irregular shapes and can be switched to the high stiffness mode for picking up heavy objects in real-time. In support of advancing the VSCRG design, engineers from CDME analyzed the design concept provided by the I-Corps team to produce a concept feasible for conventional manufacturing processes, such as injection molding or thermoforming, without sacrificing functional requirements.

A cost study of design and process selections was conducted to establish the required investment, piece cost, and tradeoffs between mass production and additive manufacturing processes.

Project challenges highlight the completion of a design that can be mass produced without sacrificing any design criteria or functional requirements. The identification of a material and process were also determined to allow for mass production.

 


Last Modified: 10/03/2022
Modified by: Michael F Gentil
